questionText: A motor car is going due north at a speed of 50 km/h. It makes a 90° left turn without changing the speed. The change in the velocity of the car is about
solutionText: Velocity is a vector quantity. When the car turns 90° left at the same speed, the change in velocity vector magnitude is given by the vector difference: Δv = √(v^2 + v^2) = v√2 = 50 × 1.414 = 70.7 km/h.

questionText: Figure shows the displacement time graph of a particle moving on the X-axis. Which of the following statements is true about the motion?
options: Particle is at rest when displacement is constant
Particle velocity is zero when graph is a straight line
Particle acceleration is maximum when displacement is maximum
Particle velocity is maximum when displacement is zero
correctAnswer: Particle is at rest when displacement is constant
solutionText: Displacement constant means no change in position over time, so velocity is zero and particle is at rest.

questionText: A particle has a velocity u towards east at t=0. Its acceleration is towards west and is constant. Let x_A and x_B be the magnitude of displacements in the first 10 seconds and the next 10 seconds respectively. Then
solutionText: Since acceleration is opposite to velocity, particle slows down. Displacement in first 10s is more than in next 10s as velocity decreases.

questionText: A person travelling on a straight line moves with a uniform velocity v_1 for some time and with uniform velocity v_2 for the next equal time. The average velocity v is given by
solutionText: Average velocity for equal time intervals is the arithmetic mean: (v_1 + v_2)/2.

questionText: A person travelling on a straight line moves with a uniform velocity v_1 for a distance x and with a uniform velocity v_2 for the next equal distance. The average velocity v is given by
solutionText: Average velocity for equal distances is given by harmonic mean: v = 2v_1v_2/(v_1 + v_2).

questionText: A stone is released from an elevator going up with an acceleration a. The acceleration of the stone after the release is
solutionText: From the elevator frame, effective acceleration is g - a downward because elevator accelerates upward.

questionText: A person standing near the edge of the top of a building throws two balls A and B. The ball A is thrown vertically upward and B is thrown vertically downward with the same speed. The ball A hits the ground with speed v_A and the ball B hits the ground with a speed v_B. We have
solutionText: Both balls cover the same vertical distance and initial speeds are equal in magnitude but opposite directions; final speeds on hitting ground are equal.

questionText: In a projectile motion the velocity
options: Remains constant in magnitude and direction
Changes in magnitude but not in direction
Changes in direction but not in magnitude
Changes in both magnitude and direction
correctAnswer: Changes in both magnitude and direction
solutionText: Projectile velocity changes due to gravity affecting vertical component, so both magnitude and direction change.

questionText: Two bullets are fired simultaneously, horizontally and with different speeds from the same place. Which bullet will hit the ground first?
solutionText: Vertical motion is independent of horizontal speed; both bullets fall under gravity and hit ground simultaneously.

questionText: The range of a projectile fired at an angle of 15° is 50 m. If it is fired with the same speed at an angle of 45°, its range will be
solutionText: Range R = (u^2 sin 2θ)/g. Since sin 30° = 0.5 and sin 90° = 1, range at 45° is twice that at 15°, so 50×2=100 m.

questionText: Two projectiles A and B are projected with angle of projection 15° for the projectile A and 45° for the projectile B. If R_A and R_B be the horizontal range for the two projectiles then
solutionText: Range is proportional to sin 2θ. Since sin 30° < sin 90°, R_A < R_B.

questionText: A river is flowing from west to east at a speed of 5 metres per minute. A man on the south bank of the river, capable of swimming at 10 metres per minute in still water, wants to swim across the river in the shortest time. He should swim in a direction
solutionText: To minimize time across, swim directly perpendicular to river flow (straight north).

questionText: In the arrangement shown in figure the ends P and Q of an inextensible string move downwards with uniform speed u. Pulleys A and B are fixed. The mass M moves upwards with a speed
solutionText: Due to string constraints and pulley arrangement, the mass moves up at speed u when ends move down at speed u.

questionText: Consider the motion of the tip of the minute hand of a clock. In one hour:
options: The distance travelled is not zero
correctAnswer: The distance travelled is not zero
solutionText: In one hour, the tip moves from one point to another on the circumference (not back to start), so displacement and distance are both nonzero.

questionText: A particle moves along the X-axis as x = u(t-2 s) + a(t-2 s)^2. Pick the correct statements:
options: Initial position at t=0 is zero
Initial position at t=2s is zero
Initial velocity at t=0 is u
Initial velocity at t=2s is u
correctAnswer: Initial position at t=2s is zero
Initial velocity at t=2s is u
solutionText: At t=2s, x=0 and velocity = u + 2a(t-2), so at t=2s, velocity = u.

questionText: An object may have:
solutionText: All combinations are possible: e.g., at turning point (a≠0, v=0), uniform motion (a=0, v≠0), at rest (a=0, v=0), accelerated motion (a≠0, v≠0).

questionText: Mark the correct statements for a particle going on a straight line:
options: If velocity is zero, acceleration must be zero
If velocity is zero, acceleration may not be zero
If acceleration is zero, velocity must be zero
If acceleration is zero, velocity may not be zero
correctAnswer: If velocity is zero, acceleration may not be zero
If acceleration is zero, velocity may not be zero
solutionText: At turning points, velocity is zero but acceleration is not. If acceleration is zero, velocity can be any constant value.

questionText: The velocity of a particle is zero at t=0. Which of the following statements are correct?
options: The acceleration must be zero at t=0
The acceleration may not be zero at t=0
The particle must be at rest at t=0
The particle may be moving at t>0
correctAnswer: The acceleration may not be zero at t=0
The particle may be moving at t>0
solutionText: Velocity zero does not imply acceleration zero (e.g., at a turning point). The particle can start moving after t=0.

questionText: The velocity time plot for a particle moving on straight line is shown in the figure. Which statements are correct?
options: Particle returns to its starting point
Particle never returns to starting point
correctAnswer: Particle returns to its starting point
solutionText: If area under v-t curve above and below time axis are equal and opposite, net displacement is zero, so particle returns to starting point.

questionText: Figure shows the position of a particle moving on the X-axis as a function of time. Which statements are correct?
options: Particle moves in positive direction only
Particle moves in negative direction only
solutionText: If the slope of x-t graph changes sign, the particle changes direction.

questionText: The acceleration of a particle as seen from two frames S1 and S2 have equal magnitudes 4 m/s². Which of the following statements are correct?
options: One is inertial, one is non-inertial
At least one frame must be inertial
solutionText: Acceleration is same in both frames only if both are inertial (or both non-inertial with same acceleration, but standard answer: both inertial).

questionText: When Neils Bohr shook hand with Werner Heisenberg, what kind of force did they exert?
solutionText: The force between two people shaking hands is due to electromagnetic interactions between the atoms in their hands.

questionText: Let E, G and N represent the magnitudes of electromagnetic, gravitational and nuclear forces between two electrons at a given separation. Then
solutionText: For two electrons, electromagnetic force is much stronger than nuclear (which is negligible at atomic distances) and gravitational (which is weakest).

questionText: The sum of all electromagnetic forces between different particles of a system of charged particles is zero.
options: True only if system is neutral
True only if system is isolated
solutionText: By Newton's third law, the force between every pair is equal and opposite, so the sum over all pairs is zero.

questionText: A 60 kg man pushes a 40 kg man by a force of 60 N. The 40 kg man has pushed the other man with a force of
solutionText: By Newton's third law, the force exerted by the 40 kg man on the 60 kg man is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction (60 N).

questionText: Mark all correct statements about fundamental forces.
options: Nuclear force acts only at very short ranges
Electromagnetic force is responsible for chemical bonding
Weak force is responsible for beta decay
correctAnswer: Nuclear force acts only at very short ranges
Electromagnetic force is responsible for chemical bonding
Weak force is responsible for beta decay
solutionText: All statements are correct descriptions of the four fundamental forces.

questionText: Which of the following pairs of forces are both short-range forces?
solutionText: Both nuclear and weak forces act only at subatomic distances, making them short-range forces.

questionText: Which force is responsible for the stability of atomic nuclei?
solutionText: The strong nuclear force binds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, overcoming the electromagnetic repulsion between protons.

questionText: Which of the following forces does not act at a distance?
solutionText: Contact forces require physical contact between objects, unlike the other forces which can act at a distance.
